Questions.QuestionString: 1. The preferred method of battery charging a Ni-Cad battery is constant. (Level 1)
Answers: A. voltage.
B. current.
C. power.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. What would you use to neutralise nicad battery spillage?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Boric acid.
B. Distilled water.
C. Bicarbonate of soda.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. Differential protection in an AC system protects against. (Level 2)
Answers: A. line-line, line-line-line, line-earth faults.
B. short circuits.
C. a reverse current flowing from the battery.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. One of the main purposes of a CSD is to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. prevent engine overload.
B. enable generators to be paralleled.
C. maintain constant load on the generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. When installing multiple batteries on aircraft, they are connected in. (Level 2)
Answers: A. series.
B. either parallel or series and switched between as an option.
C. parallel.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. What is the small pin on the DC ground power connector?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Positive to external power relay.
B. Positive to battery relay.
C. Ground or earth.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. A reduction in field strength of a DC shunt motor driving a constant load will result in. (Level 2)
Answers: A. reduced torque and increased speed.
B. increased torque and speed.
C. increased torque and reduced speed.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. What are the 2 short prongs on an AC plug for?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Using AC current to pull on interlock circuit.
B. To prevent arcing during plug connection / disconnection.
C. To help plug location/fit.

Questions.QuestionString: 9. A vibration contact voltage regulator consists of a shunt winding and a. (Level 2)
Answers: A. current regulation coil in series.
B. voltage regulating coil in series.
C. voltage regulating coil in parallel.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. What is the purpose of diode in a power GCR?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. To allow flow in the event of failure of the relay.
B. To speed up the operation.
C. To prevent back-flow of current in the EMF coil.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. Vibrating contact voltage regulator sensing coil is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. across the generator output.
B. in series with the field windings.
C. in parallel with the field windings.

Questions.QuestionString: 12. A current transformer connected across the neutral of a 3 phase generator is for. (Level 2)
Answers: A. load monitoring.
B. phase sequence monitoring.
C. differential protection.

Questions.QuestionString: 13. Wires in hot temperature areas should be bound with. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Teflon.
B. Nomex.
C. PVC.

Questions.QuestionString: 14. How may the output of a transistorised voltage regulator be described?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Variable AC.
B. Pulse width modulated DC.
C. Slightly variable DC.

Questions.QuestionString: 15. In a generator system, a stability winding is used. (Level 2)
Answers: A. in series with the field to prevent oscillations.
B. to control output current.
C. to prevent voltage overshoot.

Questions.QuestionString: 16. The trimmer resister in a carbon pile volts regulator is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. in series with the generator field.
B. in series with the generator volts coil.
C. in parallel with the generator volts coil.

Questions.QuestionString: 17. When a field relay trips the generator off-line, it can be reset. (Level 2)
Answers: A. after the fault has been cleared.
B. by cycling the generator switch.
C. on the ground only.

Questions.QuestionString: 18. In a paralleled AC generator system both A phases must be in synchronisation and. (Level 2)
Answers: A. CBA must equal ABC.
B. phase rotation does not matter.
C. CBA must equal CBA.

Questions.QuestionString: 19. During normal engine shut-down, the generator. (Level 2)
Answers: A. breaker and control relay are both tripped.
B. breaker is tripped only.
C. control relay is tripped only.

Questions.QuestionString: 20. The generator warning light will come on when. (Level 2)
Answers: A. voltage is too high.
B. voltage is above battery voltage.
C. voltage is below battery voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 21. When replacing a current transformer. (Level 2)
Answers: A. it can be fitted any way round.
B. voltage/current selection must be made prior to fitting.
C. it can only be fitted one way round.

Questions.QuestionString: 22. The economy coil on a relay. (Level 2)
Answers: A. reduces current required to hold closed.
B. makes it cheaper to make.
C. reduces current required to close.

Questions.QuestionString: 23. What is the function of the generator control relay?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Bring the generator on-line.
B. Connect the generator to the busbar.
C. Control output voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 24. A heat gun should be operated at. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 100°C above the specified.
B. 100°C below the specified.
C. the specified temperature.

Questions.QuestionString: 25. The current consumed by a DC starter motor will. (Level 2)
Answers: A. remain constant.
B. increase as the engine speed increases.
C. decrease as the engine speed increases.

Questions.QuestionString:
26. When checking SG of electrolyte of lead acid battery, what should be taken into account?. (Level
2)
Answers: A. Electrolyte temperature.
B. Battery charge.
C. Ambient temperature.

Questions.QuestionString: 27. The reactive load circuit in a multi-engined AC generator system. (Level 2)
Answers: A. modifies generator field excitation current.
B. modifies generator drive speed.
C. modifies generator field excitation voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 28. A vibrating type voltage regulator uses a volts coil. (Level 2)
Answers: A. in series with the generator output.
B. in series with the current coil.
C. in parallel with the generator output.

Questions.QuestionString: 29. A vibrating contact voltage regulator has. (Level 2)
Answers: A. a resistor in series with the points.
B. a volts coil in parallel with the points.
C. a resister in parallel with the points.

Questions.QuestionString: 30. Brush bedding-in on a starter generator can be carried out. (Level 2)
Answers: A. when 80 percent of the brush area has been previously bedded in, on the bench.
B. only off the aircraft.
C. during flight.

Questions.QuestionString: 31. What would be the cause of a low electrolyte level in a nicad battery?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Evaporation.
B. Over charging current.
C. Undercharging current.

Questions.QuestionString: 32. The method used to rapidly charge a nickel-cadmium battery utilizes. (Level 2)
Answers: A. constant current and varying voltage.
B. constant voltage and varying current.
C. constant current and constant voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 33. In a constant frequency AC system, real load sharing is achieved by regulating the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. generator drive torque.
B. generator speed.
C. voltage regulator.

Questions.QuestionString: 34. A constant speed drive unit has a warning light indication. (Level 2)
Answers: A. for low speed.
B. for low oil pressure.
C. for when it is disconnected from the generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 35. Speed of an HMG is controlled by a. (Level 1)
Answers: A. CSD unit.
B. swashplate.
C. ID unit.

Questions.QuestionString: 36. The electrolyte of a nickel-cadmium battery is the lowest when the battery is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. being charged.
B. under load condition.
C. in a discharged condition.

Questions.QuestionString: 37. How can the state-of-charge of a nickel-cadmium battery be determined?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. By the level of the electrolyte.
B. By measuring the specific gravity of the electrolyte.
C. By measuring discharge.

Questions.QuestionString: 38. In nickel-cadmium batteries, a rise in cell temperature. (Level 2)
Answers: A. causes an increase in internal resistance.
B. increases cell voltage.
C. causes a decrease in internal resistance.

Questions.QuestionString: 39. When a charging current is applied to a nickel-cadmium battery, the cells emit gas only. (Level 2)
Answers: A. toward the end of the charging cycle.
B. when the electrolyte level is low.
C. if they are defective.

Questions.QuestionString: 40. In a constant frequency AC system, reactive load sharing is achieved by regulating the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. generator speed.
B. generator drive torque.
C. voltage regulator.

Questions.QuestionString: 41. Under-frequency in an AC supply would cause. (Level 2)
Answers: A. overheating of inductive devices.
B. overvoltage of capacitive devices.
C. overspeeding of AC motors.

Questions.QuestionString: 42. In a delta connected generator. (Level 2)
Answers: A. line volts equals 1.73 phase volts.
B. phase volts equals 1.73 line volts.
C. line volts equals phase volts.

Questions.QuestionString: 43. A lead-acid battery is considered to be fully charged when the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. S.G. and voltage remain constant for specified period.
B. cells begin to gas freely.
C. S.G. reaches 1.180.

Questions.QuestionString: 44. To prevent corrosion at the terminals of a lead-acid battery. (Level 2)
Answers: A. petroleum jelly may be applied to the connections.
B. the connectors may be painted.
C. copper connectors are used.

Questions.QuestionString: 45. Two 12V 25 ampere batteries connected in series will produce. (Level 2)
Answers: A. 12V with 25 ampere hour capacity.
B. 24V with 25 ampere hour capacity.
C. 12V with 50 ampere hour capacity.

Questions.QuestionString: 46. When the temperature increases in a lead acid battery, the SG will. (Level 1)
Answers: A. decrease.
B. increase.
C. remain the same.

Questions.QuestionString:
47. On a DC shunt generator without a voltage regulator, if the load increases the generator output
voltage will. (Level 2)
Answers: A. increase.
B. remain constant.
C. decrease.

Questions.QuestionString: 48. If a nicad battery overheats, it is an indication of. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the generator voltage regulator setting is too low.
B. the generator is not connected to the bus bar.
C. thermal runaway.

Questions.QuestionString: 49. Spillage of a lead acid electrolyte is detected by. (Level 2)
Answers: A. indicating paper that turns red.
B. indicating paper that turns blue.
C. litmus paper that turns black.

Questions.QuestionString: 50. To restore electrolyte after spillage. (Level 2)
Answers: A. add a mixture of acid and water of the same s.g. as that in the battery.
B. add acid only.
C. add distilled water only.

Questions.QuestionString: 51. Single phase components in a 3 phase system may be connected between. (Level 2)
Answers: A. phases A and B only.
B. the phase and earth only.
C. any phase and earth or between any two phases.

Questions.QuestionString: 52. When operating two AC generators unparalleled, the phase of each. (Level 2)
Answers: A. is unimportant.
B. must be in opposition to one another.
C. must be synchronized.

Questions.QuestionString: 53. When the GPU is connected to the aircraft. (Level 2)
Answers: A. it supplies essential services.
B. it is not paralleled with the aircraft generator.
C. it is paralleled with the aircraft generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 54. An I.D.G (integrated drive generator). (Level 2)
Answers: A. does not require a CSDU.
B. incorporates the alternator and CSD as one unit.
C. has separate CSDU.

Questions.QuestionString:
55. In a multi-generator system, the generator which takes more than its reactive power share is
protected by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. over-voltage and under-voltage protection circuits.
B. over-current and under-current protection circuits.
C. over-excitation and under-excitation protection circuits.

Questions.QuestionString: 56. Sharing of electrical loads by paralleled DC generators is controlled by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. equalising circuits which control the field excitation of the generators.
B. automatic load shedding.
C. equalising circuits which control the speed of the generators.

Questions.QuestionString: 57. Control of hydraulically powered emergency electrical generator frequency is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. by CSU.
B. by angle of swash plate.
C. by IDG.

Questions.QuestionString: 58. Before operating generators in parallel, their voltages should be matched to prevent. (Level 3)
Answers: A. large circulating currents developing.
B. overloading the generator drive and shearing of splines.
C. voltage spikes of sufficient magnitude to trigger GCU overvoltage circuits.

Questions.QuestionString: 59. Consumer loads are connected to a busbar. (Level 3)
Answers: A. in series so when loads are shed voltage is reduced.
B. in parallel so when loads are shed current is reduced.
C. in series so when loads are shed current is reduced.

Questions.QuestionString:
60. Whilst operating paralleled AC constant frequency generators, it is important to maintain
generator outputs at the same voltage. (Level 3)
Answers:
A. to prevent a circulating current of considerable magnitude developing between two or more
generators.
B. to prevent CSD shock loading.
C. to prevent a circulating current developing between two or more TRUs.

Questions.QuestionString: 61. A voltage regulator installed in series with a generator field. (Level 3)
Answers: A. uses a voltage coil in series with generator output.
B. uses a voltage coil in parallel with generator output.
C. uses a current coil in parallel with generator output.

Questions.QuestionString: 62. CSD warning lights on the flight deck normally indicate. (Level 3)
Answers: A. high oil pressure, low oil temperaturelow oil pressure, high oil temperature.
B. low oil pressure, low oil temperature.
C. low oil pressure, high oil temperature.

Questions.QuestionString: 63. An AC generator used with a CSD. (Level 3)
Answers: A. needs a voltage controller to maintain voltage with increasing load.
B. does not need a voltage controller because current is kept constant.
C. does not need a voltage controller because voltage is kept constant.

Questions.QuestionString: 64. Abnormal CSD operation is monitored on the flight deck by observing indications of. (Level 3)
Answers: A. low oil quantity / low oil temperature.
B. high oil temperature / low oil pressure.
C. High oil temperature / low oil quantity.

Questions.QuestionString: 65. High voltages on a generator in a parallel system should be prevented because. (Level 3)
Answers: A. it will trip the GCR.
B. it will damage the drive shaft.
C. it will cause high circulating current in the bus / other generators.

Questions.QuestionString: 66. What will happen if the aircraft battery becomes overheated?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. The power supply to the battery charger will be interrupted.
B. The battery charger will switch to trickle charge mode.
C. The hot battery bus will be disconnected from the battery.

Questions.QuestionString:
67. After engine start using a Ni-Cad battery, the pilot observes on the battery charger indicator, an
initial high current draw followed by a rapid decrease in current. (Level 3)
Answers: A. there is a problem with the charging circuit and he must shut-down the engines.
B. the battery is faulty.
C. no cause for concern.

Questions.QuestionString: 68. Electrical load on aircraft is controlled by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. a BPCU.
B. an IRS.
C. a GCU.

Questions.QuestionString: 69. To confirm the state of charge of a ni-cad battery. (Level 3)
Answers: A. measure the discharge time.
B. subject the battery to load, check voltage and check the SG of each cell.
C. subject the battery to load and check the voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 70. In a carbon pile regulator, the resistive element is. (Level 3)
Answers: A. in series with the field and changes resistance with surface area contact.
B. in parallel with the field and changes resistance with changing length.
C. in series with the field and changes resistance with changing length.

Questions.QuestionString: 71. The power factor of an AC generator identifies the proportion of. (Level 3)
Answers: A. apparent power from the generator that does work.
B. real power from the generator that does work.
C. reactive power from the generator that does work.

Questions.QuestionString: 72. In an undervolt condition in an AC generator system, the most likely consequence is. (Level 3)
Answers: A. activation of the time delay circuit.
B. energise the bus tie relay.
C. deactivation of the field regulatory TRs.

Questions.QuestionString:
73. If voltage and frequency of the generator drop to zero in flight, it would be an indication that the.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. bus tie interlock is inoperative.
B. CSD driveshaft had sheared.
C. phase sequence detection circuit has operated.

Questions.QuestionString:
74. Assuming all systems are operating normally, as aircraft electrical load increases, generator
output voltage will. (Level 3)
Answers: A. increases and amperage output increases.
B. remain constant and amperage output increases.
C. decrease and amperage output increases.

Questions.QuestionString: 75. When an overvolt is present on an AC generator system, the tripping circuit. (Level 3)
Answers: A. trips after a time delay inversely proportional to overvolt amplitude.
B. trips after a time delay.
C. trips at a set level.

Questions.QuestionString: 76. In an AC distribution system, the purpose of the synchronising bus-bar is to. (Level 3)
Answers: A. provide a means of monitoring the load.
B. provide interconnection between the generator load busbars.
C. supply essential services.

Questions.QuestionString:
77. In the event of complete AC generator failure in an AC split bus-bar generation system, how is
power maintained to the essential AC bus-bar?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. By power fed from a battery supplied static inverter.
B. By power fed from a hot battery bus-bar only.
C. By power fed from static inverter only.

Questions.QuestionString:
78. Which components within a generator control unit connects the output of the field power supply
to the generator exciter?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Generator power pilot relay.
B. Generator line contactor.
C. Generator control relay.

Questions.QuestionString: 79. Topping up a Ni-Cad battery in situ. (Level 1)
Answers: A. is not allowed.
B. is only allowed in the shop.
C. is permitted.

Questions.QuestionString: 80. How is real and reactive load sharing achieved in an AC parallel generator system?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Real load by control of the constant speed drives, reactive load by adjustment of generator fields.

B. Real and reactive loads by control of the constant speed drives only. Output voltage is controlled by
adjustment of generator fields.
C. Real load by control of generator fields, Reactive loads by adjustment of the constant speed drives.

Questions.QuestionString:
81. Other than when there is a fault in an aircraft battery or its charging system, when is the charger
switched off automatically?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. When the battery is used for excessively high discharge currents such as in starting.
B. When the alternators are fully loaded.
C. When there is a failure of one alternator in a split-bus bar system.

Questions.QuestionString: 82. In a split bus power distribution system. (Level 3)
Answers: A. each generator supplies its own bus and distribution system in normal operation.
B. generators are paralleled on connection to the tie bus.
C. power is split between 115V AC and 28V DC.

Questions.QuestionString: 83. How do you check condition of Ni-Cad battery in situ?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. By voltmeter connected to the battery terminal.
B. By voltmeter in the cockpit when battery is off load.
C. By voltmeter in the cockpit, when battery is on load.

Questions.QuestionString: 84. The purpose of the economy contacts in a relay is to. (Level 3)
Answers: A. prevent contact pitting and burning.
B. reduce the current required to hold the contacts closed.
C. close the auxiliary contacts before the main contacts.

Questions.QuestionString: 85. An AC generator connected to a CSD requires. (Level 3)
Answers: A. a separate voltage regulator.
B. no voltage regulator as the CSD will control generator frequency.
C. no voltage regulator as the CSD will control the voltage.

Questions.QuestionString:
86. If electrolyte from a lead-acid battery is spilled in the battery compartment, which procedure
should be followed?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Apply sodium bicarbonate solution to the affected are followed by a water rinse.
B. Apply boric acid solution to the affected area followed by a water rinse.
C. Rinse the affected area thoroughly with clean water.

Questions.QuestionString:
87. Which statement regarding the hydrometer reading of a lead-acid storage battery electrolyte is
true?. (Level 3)
Answers:
A. A specific gravity correction should be subtracted from the hydrometer reading if the electrolyte
temperature is above 20°C.

B. The hydrometer reading will give a true indication of the capacity of the battery regardless of the
electrolyte temperature.

C. The hydrometer reading does not require a temperature correction if the electrolyte temperature is
60°F.

Questions.QuestionString:
88. An increase in the speed of a DC generator will cause the voltage to rise with the following
resultant action in the voltage regulator:-. (Level 3)
Answers: A. The volts coil to exert more pull thus increasing the current in the generator field.
B. The volts coil to increase its magnetic field thus decreasing the field excitation.
C. The volts coil to exert less pull thus increasing the resistance of the carbon pile.

Questions.QuestionString: 89. The equalizing coils on voltage regulators will. (Level 3)
Answers: A. be connected to each other when the generators are paralleled.
B. have current passing through them only when the generators are not paralleled.
C. have current passing through them from the higher loaded generator to the lower.

Questions.QuestionString: 90. Circulating currents are associated with. (Level 1)
Answers: A. AC and DC generators in parallel.
B. AC generators in parallel.
C. DC generators in parallel.

Questions.QuestionString:
91. A fully charged lead-acid battery will not freeze until extremely low temperatures are reached
because. (Level 3)
Answers: A. the acid is in the plates, thereby increasing the specific gravity of the solution.
B. increased internal resistance generates sufficient heat to prevent freezing.
C. most of the acid is in the solution.

Questions.QuestionString:
92. What determines the amount of current which will flow through a battery while it is being
charged by a constant voltage source?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. The total plate area of the battery.
B. The state-of-charge of the battery.
C. The ampere-hour capacity of the battery.

Questions.QuestionString:
93. The presence of small amounts of potassium carbonate deposits on the top of nickel-cadmium
battery cells that have been in service for time is an indication of. (Level 3)
Answers: A. normal operation.
B. excessive gassing.
C. excessive plate sulphation.

Questions.QuestionString:
94. The servicing and charging of nickel-cadmium and lead-acid batteries together in the same service
area is likely to result in. (Level 3)
Answers: A. contamination of both types of batteries.
B. increased explosion and/or fire hazard.
C. normal battery service life.

Questions.QuestionString:
95. If the current drawn from No.1 generator of a twin generator DC system is less than that drawn
from No.2 generator, the current in the No.2 generator equalizing coil will flow. (Level 3)
Answers: A. in the same direction as the current flow in the voltage coil, reducing the output of No.2 generator.
B. in the same direction as the current flow in the voltage coil, increasing the output of No.2 generator.

C. in the opposite direction to the current flow in the voltage coil, reducing the output of No.2
generator.

Questions.QuestionString:
96. On a C.S. driven generator, operation of the Disconnect Solenoid will disconnect the generator
drive and. (Level 3)
Answers: A. it will automatically reset itself when the fault is rectified.
B. it can only be reset when all loads are switched off.
C. resetting can only be carried out on the ground.

Questions.QuestionString:
97. Nickel-cadmium batteries which are stored for a long period of time will show a low fluid level
because the. (Level 3)
Answers: A. fluid evaporates through vents.
B. electrolyte becomes absorbed in the plates.
C. fluid level was not periodically replenished.

Questions.QuestionString: 98. The purpose of 'field flashing' is to. (Level 3)
Answers: A. test the insulation resistance of a field winding with a 1000V supply.
B. measure the residual magnetism in a field winding 24 hours after the field supply is removed.
C. change the polarity of residual magnetism in a field winding.

Questions.QuestionString:
99. What may result if water is added to a nickel-cadmium battery when it is not fully charged?.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. Excessive spewing will occur during the charging cycle.
B. The cell temperature will run too low for proper output.
C. No adverse results since water may be added anytime.

Questions.QuestionString: 100. The equalising coil in the carbon pile regulator. (Level 3)
Answers: A. modifies the effect of the voltage sensing coil.
B. becomes inoperative when the undervolt relay energises.
C. is connected in series with the carbon pile.

Questions.QuestionString: 101. What is the amperage at point '' to the nearest amp?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 100 Amps.
B. 101 Amps.
C. 102 Amps.

Questions.QuestionString:
102. In the procedure to be followed after spillage of battery acid, neutralizing may be carried out.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. by applying a coating of petroleum jelly.
B. with a dilute solution of sodium bicarbonate.
C. by washing with distilled water.

Questions.QuestionString:
103. To restore the level of electrolyte which has been lost due to normal gassing during battery
charging. (Level 3)
Answers: A. sulphuric acid must be added.
B. electrolyte of the same specific gravity as that contained in the battery must be added.
C. distilled water must be added.

Questions.QuestionString:
104. The only practical method of maintaining a constant voltage output from an aircraft generator
under varying conditions of speed and load is to vary the. (Level 3)
Answers: A. speed at which the armature rotates.
B. number of conductors in the armature.
C. strength of the magnetic field.

Questions.QuestionString: 105. As the generator load is increased (within its rated capacity), the voltage will. (Level 3)
Answers: A. remain constant and the amperage output will decrease.
B. remain constant and the amperage output will increase.
C. decrease and the amperage output will increase.

Questions.QuestionString: 106. When checking the specific gravity of the electrolyte in a battery. (Level 3)
Answers: A. one cell only need be checked as the remainder will read the same.
B. each cell should be checked as the readings may differ.
C. only the end cells need be checked as they contain the terminals.

Questions.QuestionString: 107. Before taking S.G. readings of a lead-acid battery recently removed from an aircraft. (Level 3)
Answers: A. the electrolyte temperature must be noted.
B. a period of 1 hour should have elapsed to allow the S.G. to stabilize.
C. the battery must be charged at the 10 hour rate for one hour.

Questions.QuestionString: 108. The specific gravity of the electrolyte in a lead-acid battery. (Level 3)
Answers:
A. remains constant with changes in the state of charge but is a useful guide to the amount of acid
contained in the electrolyte.

B. remains substantially constant regardless of the state of charge and is not therefore a guide to the
state of charge.
C. changes with the state of charge and is therefore a measure of the state of charge.

Questions.QuestionString:
109. A battery which is assumed to be 100% efficient and to have a capacity of 60 ampere-hours at
the 10 hour rate will deliver. (Level 3)
Answers: A. 6 amps for 10 hours.
B. 60 amps for 10 hours or 6 amps for 10 hours depending upon the rate of demand.
C. 60 amps for 10 hours.

Questions.QuestionString: 110. As an installed battery becomes fully charged by the aircraft generator. (Level 3)
Answers: A. the battery voltage nears its nominal level so the charging current decreases.
B. the battery contactor isolates the battery from the generator.
C. the generator voltage decreases to supply the steadily decreasing current.

Questions.QuestionString: 111. When using A.C. power on the bus bar you require 28V D.C. for battery charging. (Level 3)
Answers: A. an A.C. inverter would be required.
B. an A.C. transformer and rectifier would be required.
C. a D.C. transformer and rectifier would be required.

Questions.QuestionString: 112. What does the differential sensing coil sense?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Power.
B. Volts.
C. Current.

Questions.QuestionString: 113. Pitot tubes are heated by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. DC.
B. AC.
C. AC or DC.

Questions.QuestionString: 114. Two similar 12V batteries connected in parallel will produce. (Level 3)
Answers: A. 24V e.m.f. with the same capacity as each battery.
B. 12V e.m.f. with twice the capacity of each battery.
C. 24V e.m.f. with twice the capacity of each battery.

Questions.QuestionString: 115. When checking a nicad battery in situ for serviceability. (Level 3)
Answers: A. a load is applied to the battery and the voltmeter reading noted.
B. a hydrometer must be used.
C. the electrical circuits must be isolated before installing shorting strips.

Questions.QuestionString: 116. Load sharing on a DC generation system is achieved by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. circulating currents affecting the carbon pile for voltage trimming.
B. the load differences causing torque signals to vary the engine speed.
C. tachogenerators varying the generators outputs as the engine speed varies.

Questions.QuestionString:
117. If a nickel cadmium aircraft battery is not required for immediate service, it should be stored.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. in the fully discharged condition.
B. in a totally dry condition.
C. in the fully charged condition.

Questions.QuestionString: 118. The correct way to determine the state of charge of a nickel-cadmium battery is. (Level 3)
Answers: A. by checking the specific gravity of each cell.
B. by checking the voltage of each cell under load.
C. by a complete discharge and a measured recharge.

Questions.QuestionString: 119. A DC generator will be connected to the busbar after the RCCO contacts close due to. (Level 3)
Answers: A. increasing battery voltage.
B. increasing generator voltage.
C. a differential voltage of 0.5V battery voltage higher than generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 120. When a DC generator fails, the pilot will receive the following indications:-. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Rising voltage and current discharge with a red PFWL.
B. An audio bell and red PFWL.
C. Zero current on the ammeter and a red PFWL.

Questions.QuestionString:
121. With a vibrating-contact type voltage regulator the adjustment of generator voltage is carried
out by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. adjustment of voltage coil resistance.
B. alteration of contact spring tension.
C. alteration of the field resistance.

Questions.QuestionString: 122. Polarization in a cell is. (Level 3)
Answers: A. the fact that hydrogen bubbles form on the -ve plate.
B. the fact that as a battery discharges, the -ve plate's potential approaches that of the +ve plate's.
C. the establishing of a potential across the cell.

Questions.QuestionString: 123. Battery capacity is checked by. (Level 3)
Answers:
A. discharging while maintaining the voltage constant by varying a resistor in the circuit and checking
the time to be discharged.
B. discharging at a constant current and checking the time taken to reach the discharged state.
C. measuring the terminal voltage whilst on load and multiplying by the current drawn.

Questions.QuestionString: 124. Paralleling is used for. (Level 1)
Answers: A. AC and DC electrical generators.
B. DC electrical generators only.
C. AC electrical generators only.

Questions.QuestionString: 125. The frequency of an AC generator is dependant on the. (Level 3)
Answers: A. number of pairs of poles and the speed of the rotor.
B. number of conductors and the field strength.
C. field strength and the speed of the generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 126. Battery charging procedures can be found in ATA. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Chapter 24 Section 21.
B. Chapter 24 Section 31.
C. Chapter 31 Section 21.

Questions.QuestionString: 127. Maximum battery temperature on charging before protection circuit starts is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 144 degrees C.
B. 144 degrees F.
C. 71 degrees F.

Questions.QuestionString: 128. If an aircraft has no battery charger, the battery is charge (Level 1)
Answers: A. constant current until a predetermined limit when it automatically switches to constant voltage
B. constant current.
C. constant voltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 129. The output of a carbon pile regulator with no variation of loading is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. stationary.
B. pulse width modulating.
C. fluctuating.

Questions.QuestionString: 130. A paralleled relay for a DC system is energised and connected (Level 1)
Answers: A. zeners and transistors.
B. current coil.
C. voltage and current coil.

Questions.QuestionString: 131. When resetting the CSD on the ground, the engine should be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. rotating at Nsync.
B. rotating at idle.
C. stationary.

Questions.QuestionString: 132. How is RAT driven?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Airstream.
B. Compressor.
C. Fan.

Questions.QuestionString: 133. How is an aircraft battery rated?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Ampere hours.
B. Joules.
C. Watts.

Questions.QuestionString: 134. Where does the GCU gets its power?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. RAT.
B. Battery.
C. PMG.

Questions.QuestionString: 135. Eddy currents are. (Level 1)
Answers: A. circulating currents.
B. caused by heating effect of the coil.
C. caused by resistance of the coil.

Questions.QuestionString: 136. The small pins in the power connector plug are. (Level 1)
Answers: A. negative.
B. neutral.
C. positive.

Questions.QuestionString: 137. Zener diodes are for. (Level 1)
Answers: A. voltage stabilisation.
B. voltage regulation.
C. rectification.

Questions.QuestionString: 138. AC generator output indications are measured in. (Level 1)
Answers: A. KVA & KW.
B. KW & KVAR.
C. KW.

Questions.QuestionString: 139. Load shedding allows. (Level 1)
Answers: A. less current to the busbar.
B. more current to the busbar.
C. more voltage to the busbar.

Questions.QuestionString: 140. In what units are static inverters rated?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. kVA.
B. kVAR.
C. kW.

Questions.QuestionString: 141. On engine shutdown, what prevents GCR being tripped?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Under-volt.
B. Under-frequency.
C. Under-current.

Questions.QuestionString: 142. When loads are shed from a busbar automatically. (Level 1)
Answers: A. bus bar current decreases.
B. bus bar current rises.
C. bus bar voltage rises.

Questions.QuestionString: 143. What controls output from the generator?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. BPCU.
B. GCU.
C. ELCU.

Questions.QuestionString: 144. Specific Gravity in a lead acid battery should give an indication of. (Level 1)
Answers: A. charge.
B. electrolyte temperature.
C. electrolyte level.

Questions.QuestionString: 145. Excessive commutator sparking can be caused by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. rotating field diode failure.
B. brushes positioned on MNA.
C. weak spring tension.

Questions.QuestionString: 146. A neutralising agent for sulphuric acid is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. borax powder.
B. citric acid.
C. sodium bicarbonate.

Questions.QuestionString: 147. Flashing a generator field. (Level 1)
Answers: A. decreases resistance.
B. restores magnetism.
C. increases resistance.

Questions.QuestionString: 148. The purpose of an inverter is to convert. (Level 1)
Answers: A. DC to AC.
B. AC to DC.
C. AC to a higher frequency AC.

Questions.QuestionString: 149. The electrolyte in a lead-acid battery contains. (Level 1)
Answers: A. nitric acid.
B. sulphuric acid.
C. hydrochloric acid.

Questions.QuestionString: 150. Frequency (Hz) is the number of cycles per. (Level 1)
Answers: A. revolution.
B. second.
C. minute.

Questions.QuestionString: 151. The three voltages of a three phase generator are. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 90 degrees apart.
B. 120 degrees apart.
C. 180 degrees apart.

Questions.QuestionString: 152. A 12 volt lead-acid battery. (Level 1)
Answers: A. has 24 cells.
B. has 6 cells.
C. has 12 cells.

Questions.QuestionString:
153. The active component of an A.C. circuit is 4 amps and the reactive is 3 amps. Ammeter reading
will be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 3.4 amps.
B. 7 amps.
C. 5 amps.

Questions.QuestionString: 154. Which aircraft circuit would be most likely to use frequency wild 200V AC?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Hydraulic pump.
B. Standby compass.
C. Windscreen heating.

Questions.QuestionString: 155. The output of a DC generator is controlled by varying the. (Level 1)
Answers: A. armature current.
B. engine speed.
C. field current.

Questions.QuestionString: 156. On an AC external power plug, the interlock circuit is controlled by pins. (Level 1)
Answers: A. AB.
B. CD.
C. EF.

Questions.QuestionString:
157. A generator rated at 30 kVA power factor 0.8 has a maximum continuous power output of. (Level
1)
Answers: B. 30 kW.
C. 24 kW.

Questions.QuestionString: 158. For battery charging, the electrical supply connected to the battery must be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. AC at 50 c.p.s.
B. AC at 400 c.p.s.
C. DC.

Questions.QuestionString: 159. The output from an AC generator is taken from. (Level 1)
Answers: A. slip rings.
B. slip rings via commutator.
C. connections on the stator.

Questions.QuestionString: 160. The purpose of an inverter is to convert. (Level 1)
Answers: A. DC to AC.
B. AC to a higher frequency AC.
C. AC to DC.

Questions.QuestionString: 161. Battery SG is measured using a. (Level 1)
Answers: A. hygrometer.
B. hypsometer.
C. hydrometer.

Questions.QuestionString: 162. A battery for use on aircraft must have a capacity of. (Level 1)
163. When connecting aircraft batteries, the last lead to connect is the. (Level 1)
Answers: A. negative.
B. positive earth.
C. positive.

Questions.QuestionString: 164. In a paralleled AC generation system load sharing is for. (Level 1)
Answers: A. reactive load only.
B. real load only.
C. real and reactive load.

Questions.QuestionString: 165. A frequency wild supply would be suitable for. (Level 1)
Answers: A. instruments and navigation systems.
B. deicing loads.
C. 3-phase torque motors.

Questions.QuestionString: 166. Three 12V, 40Ah accumulators in series would give. (Level 1)
Answers: C. 36V 40Ah.

Questions.QuestionString: 167. Voltage is controlled by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the constant speed drive.
B. the voltage regulator.
C. the swashplate.

Questions.QuestionString: 168. Three 12V, 40Ah accumulators in parallel would give. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 12V 40Ah.

Questions.QuestionString: 169. An inverter can be an AC generator driven by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. an AC motor.
B. either an AC or DC motor.
C. a DC motor.

Questions.QuestionString: 170. When mixing electrolyte for lead acid batteries. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the method of mixing is unimportant.
B. add acid to water.
C. add water to acid.

Questions.QuestionString: 171. The RPM of a 6 pole, 400 Hz alternator is. (Level 1)
172. A lead-acid battery is considered to be fully charged when the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. cells begin to gas freely.
B. SG and voltage remain constant for specified period.
C. SG reaches 1.180.

Questions.QuestionString: 173. When a current transformer is disconnected, what should be done?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Terminals shorted.
B. Resistor placed across terminals.
C. Left open circuit.

Questions.QuestionString: 174. Galley loads are wired in. (Level 2)
Answers: A. parallel so load shedding will lower current consumption.
B. either series or parallel depending on the design.
C. series.

Questions.QuestionString: 175. A fuse-type current limiter. (Level 2)
Answers: A. can be used as a radio suppressor.
B. limits current flow to a load.
C. opens a circuit after a time/current condition has been exceeded.

Questions.QuestionString: 176. When a load is shed from a busbar, the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. busbar voltage decreases.
B. current consumption from the bar decreases.
C. busbar voltage increases.

Questions.QuestionString:
177. In unparalleled AC generation systems, the phase rotation of one generator in relation to the
others. (Level 2)
Answers: A. must be synchronised prior to paralleling.
B. is unimportant.
C. must be BCA.

Questions.QuestionString: 178. The ground interlock pins are numbered. (Level 1)
Answers: A. A and B.
B. C and N.
C. E and F.

Questions.QuestionString: 179. Before checking the SG of a battery recently removed from an aircraft. (Level 2)
Answers: A. take the temperature of the electrolyte.
B. carry out a capacity test.
C. allow to stabilise for one hour.

Questions.QuestionString: 180. Over-voltage protection circuits are activated. (Level 2)
Answers: A. before the over voltage limit is exceeded.
B. after a fixed time delay.
C. dependent on the magnitude of the overvoltage.

Questions.QuestionString: 181. A diode connected across a coil will. (Level 2)
Answers: A. suppress arching when relay is opening and closing.
B. prevent back EMF and allow faster switching.
C. prevent the coil being fitted the wrong way.

Questions.QuestionString: 182. Which fault does not always trip the GCR?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Under-frequency and under-volts.
B. Over-frequency and over-volts.
C. Over-frequency and under-frequency.

Questions.QuestionString: 183. Differential protection in a generating system. (Level 2)
Answers: A. detects current difference between source and load.
B. detects voltage difference between source and load.
C. uses the volts coil to trip the GCR.

Questions.QuestionString: 184. Open phase sensing on a current transformer. (Level 2)
Answers: A. is detected on generator neutral circuit.
B. is detected using all phases.
C. is detected using any phase.

Questions.QuestionString: 185. If the battery is switched off in flight, the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. captain's instruments will be powered from the standby bus.
B. battery is disconnected from bus.
C. generator voltage falls to zero.

Questions.QuestionString: 186. To flash a generator field the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. generator is on line and producing a voltage less than the flashing voltage.
B. generator rotates but is not on line.
C. generator must be stationary.

Questions.QuestionString: 187. Overflowing electrolyte in a ni-cad battery indicates. (Level 2)
Answers: A. not enough charging current.
B. excessive charging current.
C. low electrolyte temperature.

Questions.QuestionString: 188. A current transformer connected on the neutral star point of a generator is for. (Level 2)
Answers: A. overload protection.
B. differential current protection.
C. negative sequence protection.

Questions.QuestionString: 189. Distilled water should be added to a ni-cad battery. (Level 1)
Answers: A. only in the battery workshop.
B. at any time.
C. when fully charged.

Questions.QuestionString: 190. Differential protection as applied to AC generation systems compares. (Level 2)
Answers: A. generator current to busbar current.
B. generator voltage to busbar voltage.
C. ambient pressure to cabin pressure.

Questions.QuestionString: 191. In an AC generation system, the frequency and phase rotation. (Level 2)
Answers: A. must be synchronised prior to paralleling.
B. is of no consequence after paralleling.
C. must be out of phase prior to paralleling.

Questions.QuestionString: 192. Diodes are placed across a contactor to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. ensure smooth contactor operation.
B. prevent contact bounce.
C. speed up operation by reducing back EMF.

Questions.QuestionString: 193. Placing the battery master switch to off during flight will. (Level 2)
Answers: A. isolate the battery from the main busbar.
B. shut down the APU.
C. disconnect all power to the main busbar.

Questions.QuestionString: 194. The output frequency of a hydraulically driven standby generator is controlled by. (Level 2)
Answers: A. an hydraulically actuated swash plate.
B. a CSD.
C. an IDG.

Questions.QuestionString: 195. Power to a GCU is supplied. (Level 2)
Answers: A. initially by a 'field tickling' supply and then PMG output.
B. by the battery bus or rectified generator output.
C. by the generator output only.

Questions.QuestionString: 196. Trip signals for a GCR are. (Level 2)
Answers: A. overfrequency and undervoltage.
B. differential protection and undervoltage.
C. underfrequency and overcurrent.

Questions.QuestionString: 197. Over-voltage condition trips the generator. The time taken to trip the GCU depends on. (Level 2)
Answers: A. amplitude of voltage.
B. closing of fuel and hydraulic valves.
C. time delay circuit.

Questions.QuestionString: 198. A permanent magnet should have. (Level 2)
Answers: A. low retentivity, low coercivity.
B. high retentivity, low coercivity.
C. low retentivity, high coercivity.

Questions.QuestionString: 199. On testing a generator it is found to require adjusting, where would you adjust it?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. In the cockpit on the flight engineers panel.
B. On the GCU.
C. By means of a remote trimmer.

Questions.QuestionString: 200. During a normal engine shutdown, generator tripping is initiated by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. undervoltage.
B. underfrequency.
C. overcurrent.

Questions.QuestionString: 201. When a ni-cad battery is fully charged. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the electrolyte level is higher level than normal.
B. the electrolyte level is lower than normal.
C. the electrolyte level stays the same.

Questions.QuestionString:
202. A 4:1 step-up transformer receives 120VAC in its primary and has 1600 Ohms resistance in its
secondary. What is the current drawn from the source?. (Level 2)
Answers: C. 3 A.

Questions.QuestionString: 203. In a lead-acid battery after numerous checks, one cell has low reading. (Level 2)
Answers: A. It needs topping up.
B. It must be replaced.
C. It is defective.

Questions.QuestionString:
204. A short range passenger aircraft has complete electrical failure. What time duration would the
battery be expected to power essential equipment?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. 30 minutes.
B. Forever.
C. 60 minutes.

Questions.QuestionString: 205. An external power plug has two short pins. These are used for. (Level 2)
Answers: A. ground handling bus.
B. the interlock circuit.
C. a guide for correct alignment of the plug in the socket.

Questions.QuestionString: 206. The purpose of a synchronising bus bar is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. to allow monitoring and trimming from the flight deck.
B. to enable two propeller systems to be synchronised.
C. to monitor total current load.

Questions.QuestionString: 207. Generator brush bedding. (Level 2)
Answers: A. should only be done if 50% of the width and 80% of the length is already being done.
B. should not be done on the aircraft.
C. can be done on the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: 208. In a transistor voltage regulator, the voltage output is controlle (Level 2)
Answers: A. zeners and transistors.
B. diodes and transformers.
C. transformers and transistors.

Questions.QuestionString: 209. Increasing the real load primarily. (Level 2)
Answers: A. increases output voltage and increases frequency.
B. decreases output voltage.
C. decreases frequency.

Questions.QuestionString: 210. Inductive reactive load causes. (Level 2)
Answers: A. no effect on torque but produces extra heat dissipated.
B. increase in torque only.
C. increase in torque and increase in heat dissipated.

Questions.QuestionString: 211. What does the electrical power system mainly consists of
Answers: A. Generation subsystem, consumers.
B. Generation subsystem, distribution subsystem.
C. Distribution subsystem, consumers.

Questions.QuestionString: 212. How are generation and distribution split into
Answers: A. One phase and three phase
B. AC subsystem and a DC subsystem
C. One phase and multi-phase

Questions.QuestionString: 213. Which electrical power is generated by emergency generator
Answers: A. DC
B. One phase AC
C. Three phase AC

Questions.QuestionString: 214. Which AC power is generated by static inverter
Answers: A. One phase
B. Three phase
C. Two phase

Questions.QuestionString: 215. Which type of battery is used in modern aircraft
Answers: A. Lead acid battery
B. Nickel cadmium battery
C. Lead acid battery or nickel cadmium

Questions.QuestionString: 216. How does the battery provides 24 volts DC to the DC power distribution
Answers: A. On the ground and during normal flight

B. During flight in an emergency condition when A/C has total generator loss or on the ground in certain
cases.
C. During flight in an emergency condition when A/C has total generator loss only

Questions.QuestionString: 217. Which consumers are of DC power consumers
Answers: A. Battery, static inverter, DC motor, solenoid
B. Static inverter, DC motor, solenoid, transformer
C. Battery, static inverter, DC motor, solenoid, rectifier

Questions.QuestionString: 218. Concerning electrical power, what is function of bus
Answers: A. Transferring data

B. A bus connects the power source to all the electrical consumers which use the same type of electrical
power.
C. Provides a connection between the two source

Questions.QuestionString: 219. What is property of bus
Answers: A. Low resistance
B. High resistance
C. High resistance at low temperature

Questions.QuestionString: 220. How is the main AC bus normally shown on electrical schematics
Answers: A. As a single bus
B. As a single bus with a '3p' label
C. As 3 single bus

Questions.QuestionString: 221. How is the power source switching controlled
Answers: A. Manually
B. Automatically
C. Either automatically or manually

Questions.QuestionString: 222. When is engine driven generator switched automatically to the power distribution
Answers: A. Voltage and frequency are OK, aircraft in flight and no failure is detected
B. Voltage and frequency are OK and no failure is detected
C. Voltage or frequency are OK and no failure is detected

Questions.QuestionString: 223. How is ground power source switching performed
Answers: A. Always manually
B. Always automatically
C. Either automatically or manually

Questions.QuestionString: 224. Which AC power is generated by emergency generator
Answers: A. One phase
B. three phase
C. two phase

Questions.QuestionString: 225. Which component is used as the safety devices
Answers: A. fuses and circuit breakers
B. Contactor, breaker and circuit breakers
C. Contactor, breaker, fuses and circuit breakers

Questions.QuestionString: 226. Which component is used as the measuring devices
Answers: A. Transformers rectifier
B. Contactor, breaker
C. Current transformers

Questions.QuestionString: 227. Which component is used as the switching devices
Answers: A. Contactor, breaker and circuit breakers
B. Contactor, breaker
C. Contactor, breaker, fuses and circuit breakers

Questions.QuestionString: 228. How to hold the contacts of contactor in the closed state
Answers: A. A DC current flow the coil continuously
B. Only a short current pulse
C. A latching device, normally a permanent magnet, is used

Questions.QuestionString: 229. How to hold the contacts of breaker in the closed state
Answers: A. A DC current flow the coil continuously
B. Only a short current pulse
C. A latching device, normally a permanent magnet, is used

Questions.QuestionString: 230. How to switch breaker from the closed state to open/ trip state
Answers: A. Interrupt current flow the coil
B. A short pulse is fed to the coil in the opposite direction
C. A short pulse is fed to the second coil

Questions.QuestionString: 231. How to prevent over-limit current
Answers: A. A circuit breaker or fuse is installed
B. A breaker or fuse is installed
C. A circuit breaker or breaker is installed

Questions.QuestionString: 232. What is trip free type circuit breaker
Answers: A. Circuit breaker is able to open an overloaded circuit even if the control knob mechanism is blocked.
B. Circuit breaker is not able to open an overloaded circuit if the control knob mechanism is blocked.
C. Circuit breaker is able to be closed remotely.

Questions.QuestionString: 233. Which is used as circuit breaker markings
Answers: A. Safety collar, safety clip and safety tags
B. Safety clip and safety tags
C. Colored collar, safety clip and safety tags

Questions.QuestionString: 234. On modern A/C, which source is normally used as input of transformer rectifier (TR)
Answers: A. One phase AC
B. three phase AC
C. DC

Questions.QuestionString: 235. How can each part of the distribution system be supplied with electrical power
Answers:
A. Main power and essential power are supplied with electrical power from a normal source and, in
case of loss of this source, from an alternate source, emergency power are supplied with electrical
power from only source.

B. Essential power are supplied with electrical power from a normal source and, in case of loss of this
source, by an alternate source, main power and emergency power are supplied with electrical power
from only source.

C. Each part of the distribution system can be supplied with electrical power from a normal source and,
in case of loss of this source, from an alternate source

Questions.QuestionString:
236. In the event of a failure in the main power distribution or its power sources, how is the essential
power supplied
Answers: A. The remaining power source as long as any part of it is available, due to various switching functions.
B. An emergency generator or the battery.
C. The battery

Questions.QuestionString: 237. How is the emergency power distribution supplied
Answers: A. By the main power sources via the essential power distribution.
B. An emergency generator or the battery.

C. Normally by the main power sources via the essential power distribution and an emergency
generator or the battery in case of total loss of the normal power sources.

Questions.QuestionString: 238. What does main AC power distribution consists of
Answers: A. Bus, power source switching and bus tie switching
B. Generator, bus, power source switching and bus tie switching
C. Generator, GCU, bus, power source switching and bus tie switching

Questions.QuestionString: 239. Which consumers use three phase AC power source
Answers:
A. Only consumers which need all three phases at the same time to operate such as 3 phase motors and
TR units.
B. Consumers which need all three phases at the same time to operate and single phase consumers.
C. Only large loads

Questions.QuestionString:
240. Why must large loads be shed or switched off before we switch any power source on or off on
the ground
Answers: A. Reduce interrupt time
B. Save energy.
C. Improves the reliability of the power relays and prevents an overload of the power source.

Questions.QuestionString: 241. How is large load shedded
Answers: A. Automatic or manually
B. Automatic on ground or manually
C. Automatic in flight

Questions.QuestionString: 242. When is automatic load shedding available
Answers: A. An overload of generators is detected while aircraft in flight
B. An overload of generators is detected or must be prevented by the system
C. An overload of generators is detected or bus is overheat.

Questions.QuestionString: 243. How is the power source switching performed
Answers: A. By power relays that are controlled either by a generator control/ ground power unit
B. By bus tie relays that are controlled either by a generator control/ ground power unit

C. By remote controlled circuit breaker that are controlled either by a generator control/ ground power
unit

Questions.QuestionString: 244. When does a power source switching always occurs
Answers: A. An existing power source is lost or when a new power source becomes available.
B. An existing power source is lost or when a new power source becomes available or a load is shedded.
C. When a new power source becomes available or a load is shedded.

Questions.QuestionString:
245. Concerning isolated operation, what happen if one generator supplies the complete electrical
power distribution.
Answers: A. An automatic load shedding occurs
B. Nothing happened
C. An manual load shedding must be taken place

Questions.QuestionString: 246. Which load is shedded to prevent an overload
Answers: A. Lighting load
B. Antice load
C. Large load such as oven, coffee maker, ect

Questions.QuestionString: 247. Concerning isolated operation, what is main purpose of bus tie push button.
Answers: A. Switch off all power source
B. Prevent bus tie switching in case of smoke in the cockpit generated by a short circuit.
C. Switch off all AC power source

Questions.QuestionString: 248. When is parallel operation allowed
Answers: A. Generators have the same voltage and frequency and phase angle.
B. Generators have the same voltage and frequency
C. Generators have the same voltage and frequency and power

Questions.QuestionString: 249. When is an automatic bus tie switching in parallel operation performed.
Answers: A. A serious problem in the distribution like a short circuit is detected or during landing
B. A serious problem in the distribution like a short circuit is detected or during automatic landing
C. A serious problem in the distribution like a short circuit is detected

Questions.QuestionString: 250. For aircraft with multi external power sources, how ground power sources synchronized.
Answers: A. By the generator control units.
B. By logic circuit
C. Ground power sources cannot be synchronized

Questions.QuestionString:
251. What happen when power source switching is performed from one power source to another one
which is not allowed to work in parallel
Answers: A. No loss of power occurs
B. A loss of power for about a tenth of a second normally occurs
C. A loss of power for about a tenth of a second normally occurs if switching is performed in flight

Questions.QuestionString: 252. What is purpose of the essential power distribution
Answers:
A. Supplies all the systems that are necessary to operate the aircraft safely in electrical emergency
configuration.
B. Supplies all the systems that are necessary to operate the aircraft safely during automatic landing
C. Supplies all the systems that are necessary to operate the aircraft safely.

Questions.QuestionString: 253. Which power distribution most important equipment is connected to
Answers: A. The essential power distribution
B. The emergency power distribution
C. The main power distribution

Questions.QuestionString: 254. Which power sources does the emergency power distribution is normally supplied from
Answers: A. The same power sources as the essential power distribution or emergency power sources
B. Emergency power sources
C. Battery

Questions.QuestionString: 255. What is electrical emergency power source
Answers: A. Battery and ram air turbine
B. Battery
C. Battery and emergency generator

Questions.QuestionString:
256. In electrical emergency configuration while emergency generator is not ready, how is emergency
power distribution normally supplied
Answers: A. From aircraft battery via a static inverter
B. From aircraft battery via a transformer rectifier (TR)
C. From aircraft battery directly and via a static inverter

Questions.QuestionString: 257. How does emergency generator supplies power to Essential and Emergency Busses
Answers: A. Supplies AC power directly and DC power via essential transformer rectifier unit
B. Supplies AC power directly only (battery supplies AC power)
C. Supplies DC power directly and AC power via static inverter.

Questions.QuestionString:
258. During the time the aircraft is parked, what must do to prevents a discharge of the battery by the
emergency equipment.
Answers: A. All batteries must be switched off
B. All batteries must be switched on
C. All batteries must be switched on and charged daily

Questions.QuestionString: 259. How is hot battery bus connected to the battery
Answers: A. Batteries must be switched off
B. It is always connected directly
C. Batteries must be switched on

Questions.QuestionString:
260. A/C in flight, both of the main AC busses are lost and batteries is only power source, what
happen to essential busses
Answers: A. Automatically shed.
B. Automatically supplied
C. Nothing happen

Questions.QuestionString: 261. How to prevent an accidental deployment of the RAT
Answers: A. A circuit is used to inhibit deployment of the RAT on ground
B. The manual ON pushbutton is guarded

C. Deployment of the RAT is only performed when the manual ON pushbutton is press and hold for 10
second

Questions.QuestionString: 262. What does a three phase AC power relay consist of
Answers: A. A high power main contacts which are operated by three electro magnetic device.

B. Three high power main contacts and each contact is operated by an electromagnetic device
individually.
C. Three high power main contacts which are operated by an electro magnetic device.

Questions.QuestionString: 263. What does breaker need to close the contacts
Answers: A. A DC current flow the coil continuously
B. A AC current flow the coil continuously
C. Only a short current pulse

Questions.QuestionString: 264. What is advantages of breaker over the contactor
Answers: A. The coil can be smaller because no heat is produced in the coil during the closed state

B. The coil can be bigger because no heat is produced in the coil during the closed state and stays closed
even when no electrical power is available.

C. The coil can be smaller because no heat is produced in the coil during the closed state and stays
closed even when no electrical power is available.

Questions.QuestionString: 265. Why the over-limit current must be prevented
Answers:
A. A over-limit current is caused by a short circuit or faulty consumer and can overheat the wire and
generate a fire.
B. For energy saving
C. To increase life of component

Questions.QuestionString: 266. For maintenance purposes, what is advantages of circuit breakers over fuses
Answers:
A. They can be reset quickly and can also be used as manual on - off switches to allow deactivation of
circuits.

B. They can be replaced quickly and can also be used as manual on - off switches to allow deactivation
of circuits.
C. They is the easiest method of overcurrent protection

Questions.QuestionString: 267. How does a circuit breaker work
Answers:
A. When the actual current exceeds the maximum permitted current, the temperature of the bimetal
increases and starts bending so the electrical circuit is opened

B. When the actual current exceeds the maximum permitted current, the resistance of the bimetal
increases and a circuit detect increasing to open electrical circuit.

C. When the actual current exceeds the maximum permitted current, the magnetic field increases and
moves the armature and the contacts to open electrical circuit

Questions.QuestionString: 268. What does the time that is needed to release a circuit breaker depend on
Answers: A. Cross section of the wire
B. The current that exceeds the nominal value.
C. Maximum allowed current

Questions.QuestionString: 269. When is the reset of a circuit breaker possible
Answers: A. The bimetal is bent
B. Bimetal has returned to its normal shape
C. About 1 minutes since circuit breaker is tripped

Questions.QuestionString:
270. In some modern aircraft types, what happen when circuit breakers with green control knobs is
tripped
Answers:
A. Caution message, name and location of the open circuit breaker is presented on display to allows an
easy identification of the circuit breaker

B. Name and location of the open circuit breaker is presented on display to allows an easy identification
of the circuit breaker
C. Nothing happen

Questions.QuestionString: 271. What is advantage of electronic circuit breaker
Answers: A. Save weight and space in the cockpit and that it is possible to change the trip values via rheostat

B. Save weight and space in the cockpit and that it is possible to change the trip values of the virtual
circuit breaker by loading of a new software.

C. Save weight and space in the cockpit and that it is possible to change the trip values via variable
capacitor

Questions.QuestionString: 272. What is purpose of fuse of electronic circuit breaker
Answers: A. To protect electronic circuit breaker

B. Fuse works as a safety backup in case of a short circuit, if the electronic circuit does not work
properly.
C. To protect shunt of electronic circuit breaker

Questions.QuestionString: 273. What are advantages of 3-phase electrical power systems
Answers:
A. Easy and economic to use, neutral current which flows via the structure during normal operation is
very big

B. easy and economic to use, neutral current which flows via the structure during normal operation is
always 0

C. easy and economic to use, neutral current which flows via the structure during normal operation is
very small.

Questions.QuestionString: 274. Concerning CSD (Constant Speed Drive), which mode is used during cruise
Answers: A. Overdrive operation.
B. Straight drive operation.
C. Underdrive operation.

Questions.QuestionString: 275. How is the phase angle difference of two power source reduced to zero
Answers: A. No way

B. Voltage differences of two power source is used as correction signal to produces a small frequency
difference
C. Two power source is reset at the same time.

Questions.QuestionString: 276. What is the purpose of the differential protection circuit
Answers: A. To detect voltage difference of two phases of 3-phase generator
B. To detect frequency difference of two phases of 3-phase generator
C. To detect short circuits in areas where circuit breakers are not usable

Questions.QuestionString: 277. How can voltage and frequency failures of a generator in parallel operation be detected
Answers: A. By a load protection loop.
B. By the voltage and frequency protection circuit.
C. By a load division loop.

Questions.QuestionString:
278. How to ensures an external power source cannot be permanently switched on if the connection
is not performed completely
Answers: A. A cable holding strap which supports the cable weight is installed

B. A small TR unit inside the GPCU, converts the three phase AC to 28 volts DC that is sent back to
external power source to holds the power relay of energized.
C. The three phase AC is sent back to external power source to holds the power relay of energized

Questions.QuestionString: 279. What is purpose of the bus tie switching
Answers: A. Provides a connection between the two busses, between the two source (only parallel operation)
B. Provides a connection between the two busses, between the two source (only isolated operation)
C. Provides a connection between the two busses, between the two source

Questions.QuestionString: 280. What is isolated operation
Answers: A. One power source work at a time
B. The power sources work in isolation from each other

C. The power sources share the same
amount of load

Questions.QuestionString: 281. In parallel operation, how are generators are synchronized
Answers: A. Manually controlled
B. Automatically controlled by logic circuit
C. Automatically controlled and monitored by the generator control units

Questions.QuestionString: 282. In isolated operation, how is bus tie controlled
Answers: A. By the generator control units.
B. By logic circuit
C. By the generator control units and by logic circuit

Questions.QuestionString: 283. What are main advantages of parallel operation over isolated operation
Answers:
A. All generators share the same part of the total load and there is no power interruption when one or
several generators are switched off
B. Reduce complication of generator control units operation
C. High redundant for avionic equipment

Questions.QuestionString:
284. A four engines aircraft is operating with all generators in parallel operation, what happen when
bus tie 1 push button on the electrical control panel is released
Answers: A. Remaining generators supplies all AC load
B. Generator 1 supplies all AC load

C. All busses are still powered, but generator 1 supplies AC bus 1, isolated from the remaining
distribution, like in an aircraft with an isolated power distribution

Questions.QuestionString:
285. Which type of operation does aircraft electrical system operate in when multi external power
sources are supply to aircraft and other power sources is not available
Answers: A. Isolated operation
B. Parallel operation
C. Isolated or parallel operation

Questions.QuestionString:
286. How to prevent the problems of power interruption when AC power source switching is
performed from one power source to another one which is not allowed to work in parallel
Answers:
A. AC power sources is convert to DC, supply converted DC power source in parallel, switch off old
power source.
B. A synchronization of the two different power sources is started before switching
C. Power interruption don't need prevent

Questions.QuestionString:
287. On an aircraft equipped with an electrical flight control system, why must MAIN DC power
distribution always work in isolated operation
Answers:
A. To prevents a single failure such as a short circuit, from affecting the complete flight control system
all at once.
B. To save energy
C. To prevents an overload of the power source.

Questions.QuestionString: 288. How Ram Air Turbine driven emergency generator
Answers: A. Generates the hydraulic power needed for the hydraulically driven
B. Drives the emergency generator directly

C. Either generates the hydraulic power needed for the hydraulically driven emergency generator or
drives the emergency generator directly

Questions.QuestionString:
289. During electrical emergency configuration (both of the main AC busses are lost), when the
emergency generator is not available, which power source supply electrical power for aircraft
Answers: A. Batteries take over automatically, it can only supply the most important equipment.
B. Batteries take over automatically, it can supply all the essential equipment for flying the aircraft
C. Batteries take over manually, it can only supply the most important equipment.

Questions.QuestionString: 290. How is activation of the emergency generator performed manually
Answers: A. On the ground only
B. In flight only
C. In flight or on ground

Questions.QuestionString: 291. Concerning over-limit current, which component protect generator feeder lines
Answers: A. Fuses or circuit breakers
B. A breaker or fuse is installed
C. The electronic circuits of the generator control unit (GCU)

Questions.QuestionString: 292. How does a fuse work
Answers: A. Like a shear pin in a mechanical linkage
B. Like a rigging pin in a mechanical linkage
C. Like a safety pin in a mechanical linkage

Questions.QuestionString: 293. Which action must be done when a fuse is blown
Answers: A. Fuse must be reset after repairing the affected circuit
B. Fuse must be replaced without any action is taken place
C. Fuse must be replaced after repairing the affected circuit

Questions.QuestionString: 294. Why is use of slip rings and brushes for current transferring not used on aircraft generators
Answers: A. It has a low reliability and produces sparks.
B. It has a high reliability but produces sparks.
C. It don't produces sparks but has low reliability.

Questions.QuestionString: 295. What is main function of rotating rectifier in modern brushless generator
Answers:
A. Rectify alternating current from PMG (Permanent Magnets Generator) to generate exciter current of
main generator.

B. Rectify alternating current from main generator to generate exciter current of PMG (Permanent
Magnets Generator).
C. Rectify alternating current from exciter generator to generate exciter current of main generator.

Questions.QuestionString: 296. What is purpose of switch of static inverter
Answers: A. Induces an sinusoidal current into the primary winding of the transformer of static inverter
B. Change direction of current in the primary winding of the transformer of static inverter
C. Protect primary winding of the transformer of static inverter

Questions.QuestionString:
297. What happen if constant speed drive (CSD) is disconnect while the input speed is too low (not
stop).
Answers:
A. The centrifugal force cannot open the clutch completely, this can lead to a clutch damage, such as
broken teeth.
B. CSD is disconnect as normal
C. Worm gear can be damaged

Questions.QuestionString: 298. In the parallel operation, what is task of regulations function of generator control unit (GCU)
Answers:
A. Ensure that all generators share the same load and synchronise power sources before a generator
power source can be switched into parallel to another power source

B. Ensure that all generators share the
same load

C. Synchronise power sources before a generator power source can be switched into parallel to another
power source

Questions.QuestionString:
299. What happen if a manual trip is performed by releasing the corresponding generator pushbutton
switch
Answers: A. Generator control relay open, exciter current is cut off, generator power relay open
B. Generator control relay open, generator power relay open
C. Generator power relay open,

Questions.QuestionString: 300. When does transformer rectifier (TR) have low current
Answers: A. An internal failure occur
B. An overload occur
C. Short circuit occur

Questions.QuestionString:
301. What happen to a nickel cadmium battery when it is overheated during charging with constant
voltage charging method
Answers: A. The battery output voltage increases that result in a thermal runaway
B. The battery output voltage reduce that result in a thermal runaway
C. The battery output voltage do not change
